p: Studies of adult longevity and temperature are generally in better agreement, with decreased longevity at higher temperatures in ranges from 15.0 °C to 32.0 °C [ 72, 73, 81, 82, 83] and thermal thresholds for Culex survival generally estimated at ~34.0 °C [ 72, 78]. The effect of temperature on the Aedes species may be less pronounced, although studies with enzootic vectors such as Ae. triseriatus and Ae. japonicus are limited [ 84, 85]. As with vector competence, studies with Ae. albopictus and Ae. aegypti are more numerous and have generally demonstrated unimodal relationships for temperature and longevity, with higher optimal temperatures and thermal thresholds than enzootic vectors which generally originate from more temperate areas [ 54, 86, 87].
